conclusion: Both droplets have the same mass m0.
Before the electric field is switched on they fall the distance h1 in the time t with a constant (terminal) speed v1 = h1 / t.
At terminal speed the net force on a droplet is zero, so for each droplet weight = air-drag, m0 g = k m0^(1/3) v1.
Solve m0 g = k m0^(1/3) v1 for the drag constant k, k = m0 g /(m0^(1/3) v1) = m0^(2/3) g / v1.
Express v1 through the experimentally measured quantities h1 and t, v1 = h1 / t ⇒ 1/v1 = t / h1.
Insert v1 = h1 / t into the expression for k, k = m0^(2/3) g · (t / h1).
Final answer: k = m0^(2/3) g t / h1.
